In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status  
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Public–Private Infrastructure Advisory Facility (PPIAF) was established in July 1999 
at the initiative of the governments of Japan and the United Kingdom, working closely with the 
World Bank. This multidonor technical assistance (TA) facility was set up to assist developing 
countries  to  improve  the  quality  of  their  infrastructure  through  private  participation  in 
infrastructure (PPI). PPIAF helps to facilitate private sector involvement in financing, ownership, 
operation,  rehabilitation,  maintenance,  or  management  of  infrastructure  services.  Eligible 
infrastructure services assisted by PPIAF are roads, ports, airports, railways, electricity supply, 
telecommunications,  solid  waste,  water  supply  and  sewerage,  and  gas  transmission  and 
distribution. 
 
2.  Through the PPIAF contribution, this TA will develop knowledge to address barriers to 
PPI in low-income countries in Asia and the Pacific. Partnering with PPIAF will not only be a 
cost-effective  way  to  support  development  activities  (thereby  benefiting  from  additional 
resources of PPIAF) but will also allow the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to gain knowledge 
on developing the enabling environment for PPI in low-income countries through its involvement 
in PPIAF. The concept paper for this TA was approved on 16 November 2009 by the Vice-
President  for  Knowledge  Management  and  Sustainable  Development. 1  The  design  and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.  
  
II.  ISSUES 
3.    ADB estimates that investment in infrastructure must reach an estimated $4.7 trillion 
over the next 10 years to sustain growth in Asia and the Pacific.2 Therefore, countries will need 
to spend an estimated 6%–7% of their gross domestic products on infrastructure. However, their 
recent public sector investment has averaged only 3%–4% of their gross domestic products, 
leaving a significant financing shortfall. Thus, support is needed to create the right access and 
incentives  for  PPI.  The  private  sector,  however,  is  reluctant  to  allocate  scarce  project 
development funds and capital to projects in many low-income countries because of the high-
risk nature of early-stage infrastructure development. These risks arise from uncertainties in 
regulatory, institutional, and political environments and include currency, credit, and market risks. 
Other barriers to PPI involve (i) lack of suitable infrastructure projects for investment, (ii) high 
up-front costs of project development, (iii) shortage of long-term debt, (iv) lack of local currency 
funding, (v) high revenue risk, and (vi) inadequate capacity in both the public and private sectors.  
 
4.  The mission of PPIAF is to help eliminate poverty and achieve sustainable development 
in developing countries by facilitating PPI. PPIAF pursues its mission through two mechanisms: 
(i) TA  to governments in  developing  countries  on  strategies  and measures to  tap  the full 
potential  of  PPI;  and  (ii)  identification,  dissemination,  and  promotion  of  good  practices  on 
matters related to PPI in developing countries. The PPIAF mission resonates with ADB’s aim to 
play a catalytic role in increasing PPI for poverty reduction and economic growth in Asia and the 
Pacific, as set out in ADB’s long-term strategic framework 2008–2020 (Strategy 2020).3 Strategy 
2020 acknowledges that PPI will be harder to achieve in ADB’s low-income developing member 
countries (DMCs) and that further experience and knowledge is needed to enable such PPI. 
Because of the recent financial and economic crisis, even greater effort will be required in the

5.  ADB joined PPIAF in 2001 by contributing an initial $250,000 to the trust fund to cover 
the 12 months from 1 January 2001. Thereafter, ADB renewed its funding support for 8 years to 
July 2009. The current trust fund agreement with PPIAF has been extended to 31 October 2012 
to allow implementation of an ongoing PPIAF-funded TA.4 The present TA for $500,000 renews 
ADB’s membership for 2 years from the date of signing a revision to the current trust fund 
agreement, and will permit new TA funding for projects presented by ADB to PPIAF.  
 
6.  Contributing to PPIAF offers ADB the opportunity to support the enabling environment 
for PPI as well as allowing ADB to benefit from both knowledge generated by PPIAF and 
funding leveraged from other donors. ADB is a member of PPIAF Program Council, which 
includes representatives of all contributing donor agencies, so ADB has a role in the strategic 
management of PPIAF. Results from the independent strategic review of PPIAF operations 
conducted  in  2008  validated  the  relevance  of  the  facility’s  core  mandate  of  supporting 
infrastructure services through public–private partnerships (PPPs).5 With strong donor support, 
PPIAF  is  a  good  example  of  a  global  partnership  working  to  catalyze  PPI.  A  key 
recommendation of the strategic review was that regional development banks, such as ADB, be 
better integrated into PPIAF.  
 
7.  ADB is a partner institution along with the World Bank Institute, the Inter-American 
Development Bank and the Multilateral Investment Fund in jointly developing the Multilateral 
Public–Private Partnership in Infrastructure Capacity Development Program with PPIAF funding, 
and is trying to harmonize its PPP knowledge management and dissemination activities with this 
program. ADB is also contributing TA funding to the Private Infrastructure Development Group 
(PIDG), a multi-donor initiative to support private sector investment in low-income countries. The 
PIDG collaborates closely with PPIAF on its annual TA work program.  
 
8.  PPIAF  is  governed  by  the  Program  Council,  consisting  of  representatives  from 
contributing  donors.  The  council  is  responsible  for  defining  PPIAF  policies  and  strategies, 
approving  the  indicative  annual  work  program  and  financial  plan,  and  reviewing  PPIAF 
performance. It is also responsible for approving individual project submissions. It meets once a 
year to review the strategic direction of the PPIAF program. The Technical Advisory Panel, 
composed of up to six independent experts in matters related to PPI in developing countries, 
ensures the quality and relevance of PPIAF-financed activities. A Program Management Unit 
(PMU) is responsible for day-to-day management of PPIAF in pursuit of its mandate. The PMU 
reports to the Program Council at least quarterly through the council’s chair—the World Bank’s 
vice-president for sustainable development (Appendix 2). 
 
9.  PPIAF has a two-tier financial structure comprising a core fund and noncore funds. The 
core fund contains a pool of resources that can be used for any activity falling within the work 
program approved by the Program Council. The funds may be applied to governance costs, 
country-specific activities, and activities across several countries. Noncore funds include donor 
agency restrictions relating to specific themes or activities.

10.  From  2001  to  2009,  ADB  has  contributed  $1,750,000  to  PPIAF.  The  facility  has 
approved 13 ADB-initiated TA projects worth $2,816,440 (Appendix 3). In the initial period of 
membership from 2001 to 2005, the World Bank hired consultants for ADB TA projects using 
World Bank procurement policies and guidelines. During this period, ADB was able to leverage 
funding from the core fund as well as from ADB’s own contribution, hence the larger amount for 
approved projects than actual contribution by ADB. In 2006, ADB and PPIAF agreed that ADB 
could use ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to time) and Guidelines 
on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time) for the procurement of goods 
and services for PPIAF-financed TA projects. However, this agreement is restricted to ADB’s 
own contribution held by PPIAF and does not cover the core fund or other noncore funds, which 
are still governed by World Bank procurement policies and guidelines. 
 
11.  PPIAF has advised that, for ADB to access funding from the core fund or other noncore 
funds, PPIAF would have to request all contributors to the core fund or respective noncore fund 
to prepare an addendum to their grant agreements to allow ADB to implement PPIAF-funded TA 
projects  financed  from  the  core  fund  or  other  noncore  funds  using  ADB’s  Procurement 
Guidelines and Guidelines on the Use of Consultants. PPIAF has also advised that, given that 
World Bank procurement and consultant policies allow procurement of goods and services 
produced by all countries (with limited exceptions), contributors to the core fund and other 
noncore  funds  are  not  inclined  to  accept  the  nationality  restrictions  attached  to  ADB’s 
Procurement Guidelines and Guidelines on the Use of Consultants. ADB would, therefore, in 
parallel have to pursue a waiver of these nationality restrictions from ADB’s Board of Directors. 
Given  the  number  of  contributors  involved,  PPIAF  has  requested  that  this  matter  first  be 
discussed in the PPIAF annual meeting to be held in the first quarter of 2010.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
12.  The main impact of this TA will be improved quality and quantity of infrastructure in 
ADB’s DMCs through private sector involvement. This will be achieved through (i) improved 
capacity of DMC governments to design and execute private infrastructure projects; (ii) an 
increased  number  of  pioneering  transactions  involving  the  private  sector;  (iii)  improved 
consensus on policy, regulatory, and institutional reforms within DMCs to improve the enabling 
environment for private sector participation; and (iv) an increase in infrastructure development 
strategies in DMCs. The expected outcome will be enhanced assistance for DMC governments 
to mobilize additional resources to initiate studies on PPI and provide ADB access to PPI 
studies conducted under PPIAF. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
13.   Funding support from this TA will enable ADB to continue its partnership with PPIAF. 
ADB’s continued membership will provide ongoing benefits to ADB’s DMCs as well as additional 
resources for promoting PPI in DMCs. The TA will support advisory and related activities, 
including 
 
(i)  framing infrastructure development strategies to take full advantage of the potential 
for private involvement; 
(ii)  building consensus on appropriate policy, regulatory, and institutional reforms; 
(iii)  designing and implementing specific policy, regulatory, and institutional reforms;

6 
 
(iv)  supporting the design and implementation of pioneering projects and transactions; 
and 
(v)  building  government  capacity  to  design  and  execute  private  infrastructure  and 
arrangements for, and regulation of, private service providers. 
 
14.   The TA will provide a membership contribution to PPIAF. It will thus help to meet the 
cost of consulting services recruited by ADB as well as other eligible expenses for undertaking 
ADB-initiated  PPIAF  projects  designed  to  encourage  PPI.  Through  its  membership  in  the 
Program Council, ADB will play an important role in steering PPIAF project activities. In most 
cases,  these  projects  will  further  the  poverty  reduction  objectives  of  ADB  and  generally 
complement studies proposed by ADB in its private sector development strategy6 and ADB 
strategic priorities as set out in Strategy 2020. 
 
15.  Leveraging  of  PPIAF  core  funds  is  critical  to  ADB’s  involvement  in  PPIAF.  ADB, 
therefore, only wishes to make this next contribution to PPIAF after the following two conditions 
have been satisfied: 
(i)  the PPIAF donors have agreed that ADB may apply its Procurement Guidelines 
and Guidelines on the Use of Consultants for the procurement of goods and 
services for PPIAF-financed activities from the core fund and noncore funds 
where applicable; and  
(ii)  the Board has waived the requirement that PPIAF funds administered by ADB 
may only be used to finance procurement in ADB member countries of goods 
and services produced in member countries.  
ADB will enter into an agreement with the World Bank for its contribution to PPIAF.   
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
16.   ADB will contribute $500,000 to PPIAF, which will be used to finance consulting services 
and other costs.7 The TA will be financed by ADB on a grant basis from ADB’s TA Special Fund 
(TASF-other).  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
17.  The implementation arrangements for ADB’s involvement in PPIAF are set forth in and 
governed by the PPIAF trust fund agreement and the guidelines signed by PPIAF and ADB on 
29 June 2005, as revised by the amendment letter signed on 5 October 2006. Under the 
amended agreement, overall project management of ADB-initiated PPIAF projects is delegated 
to ADB. As such, procurement of goods and services will follow ADB’s Procurement Guidelines 
(2007, as amended from time to time) and Guidelines on the Use of Consultants. Assuming the 
conditions in paragraph 15 have been satisfied, a revision to the trust fund agreement will be 
prepared and reflect the conditions around ADB’s access to core funds and other noncore 
funds. 
 
18.  ADB’s contribution will be provided after successful discussion and signing of a trust 
fund agreement between the trust fund administrator (the World Bank) and ADB. The TA will be 
implemented from the date of signing the trust fund agreement for a 24 month-period, the latest

agreed utilization closing date. The World Bank will recover a small charge for costs associated 
with administering the trust funds which will be clearly stated in the trust fund agreement.  
 
19.  The Office of Cofinancing Operations (OCO) is expected to administer the TA. OCO, 
together with the Energy, Transport and Water Division (RSID) of the Regional and Sustainable 
Development Department, will facilitate preparation of ADB applications for PPIAF grants. OCO 
will coordinate ADB-initiated PPIAF projects, act as an intermediary with the PMU, and work 
with the PMU to monitor closely all ongoing ADB-initiated PPIAF projects. Once individual 
projects  are  approved  by  the  PPIAF  Program  Council  and  by  ADB,  responsibility  for 
implementation will lie with the division that initiates the PPIAF proposal. 8  The OCO project 
officer for this TA will disseminate information within ADB as follows: (i) establish a virtual group 
of staff members who will be kept informed of PPIAF activities, (ii) share reports and outputs of 
activities with virtual group and relevant staff, (iii) share knowledge products and reports from 
PPIAF with the virtual group and relevant staff, and (iv) share lessons and information through 
ADB workshops and communities of practice.  
 
20.  The World Bank has instituted an annual single audit exercise for all trust funds. The 
project officer for each approved activity is required to confirm to PPIAF that he or she has 
complied with the terms set forth in the PPIAF award letter; has exercised due diligence with 
respect to the administration, management, and monitoring of the funds; and has ensured that 
all  expenses  and  disbursements  accord  with  World  Bank  procurement  and  administrative 
guidelines  (or  in  the  case  of  ADB’s  contribution,  with  ADB’s  Procurement  Guidelines  and 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants) PPIAF provides Program Council members with quarterly 
progress reports on the status of approved activities. This TA does not trigger ADB safeguard 
requirements, so use of ADB safeguard policies will not be mandatory. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to 
the Public–Private Infrastructure Advisory Facility for the Contribution to the Public–Private 
Infrastructure Advisory Facility, and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
                                                
8  Since ADB project officers will develop proposals (which will include proposed activities, terms of reference for 
consultants, financing plans, and proposed procurement arrangements) and submit these to the Program Council 
and/or PMU for review and no objection, it is not possible at the moment to provide precise cost estimates, 
financing plans, or consultant terms of reference.

PUBLIC–PRIVATE INFRASTRUCTURE ADVISORY FACILITY GOVERNANCE STRUCTURE 
AND FINANCES 
 
A.  Organization Structure.  
 
1.  Program Council. The Program Council is made up of representatives of contributing 
donors  who  meet  once  per  year  to  review  the  strategic  direction  of  the  Public–Private 
Infrastructure  Advisory  Facility  (PPIAF)  program,  its  achievements,  and  its  financing 
requirements.1 The program council is chaired by a designated representative of the World 
Bank and is responsible for 
(i)  considering and defining the policies and strategies of PPIAF; 
(ii)  approving the annual work program and financing plan; 
(iii)  reviewing  PPIAF’s  performance,  including  selecting  activities  for  ex-post 
evaluation by the Technical Advisory Panel (TAP); and 
(iv)  overseeing the TAP and the Program Management Unit (PMU). 
 
2.  Technical Advisory Panel. The Program Council is supported by the independent TAP 
whose  members  are  leading  international  experts  in  different  aspects  of  public–private 
partnerships (PPPs) in infrastructure. The chair of the Program Council appoints TAP members 
after consultation with the Program Council members. The TAP is responsible for  
(i)  providing advice, at the request of the Program Council, on issues relating to 
private participation in infrastructure (PPI) in developing countries; 
(ii)  reviewing and commenting on PPIAF strategy as reflected in draft annual work 
programs prepared by the PMU; and 
(iii)  evaluating  the  impact  of  the  PPIAF  annual  work  program  through  ex-post 
evaluation of selected activities. 
 
TAP members meet around twice per year and attend the Program Council annual meeting. 
The TAP conducts ex-post reviews of selected activities as part of its regular responsibility for 
independent evaluation of the impact of the PPIAF program.  
 
3.  Program  Management  Unit.  PPIAF  is  managed  by  a  PMU  in  accordance  with  a 
general strategy laid out in PPIAF’s charter and in the annual work programs approved by the 
Program Council. The unit is small, focusing on administering the PPIAF program rather than 
delivering  activities.  PPIAF  relies  extensively  on  external  consultants  to  deliver  activities, 
following  World  Bank  guidelines  on  procurement  and  hiring  of  consultants.  PMU  key 
responsibilities include 
(i)  reviewing proposals for assistance in accordance with the criteria and process 
approved by the Program Council (for activities funded from the core fund) or by 
relevant contributors (for activities funded from noncore funds); 
(ii)  arranging for delivery of PPIAF programs and activities; 
(iii)  providing secretariat services to the Program Council and TAP; 
(iv)  maintaining effective relationships with contributors, recipient governments, the 
private sector, and other stakeholders;

(v)  proposing and administering the PPIAF work plan and budget, and managing the

(vi)  overseeing the operation of the field-based regional coordination offices. 
 
4.  Regional Coordination Offices. PPIAF has four regional coordination offices (Figure 
A2), which have the following key responsibilities: 
(i)  identifying  opportunities  for  PPIAF  assistance,  supporting  local  requests  for 
PPIAF interventions, and tailoring assistance to local priorities and conditions; 
(ii)  working  with  recipient  governments  and  contributors,  international  financial 
institutions,  and  other  official  agencies  to  promote  effective  coordination  of 
advisory activities; 
(iii)  consulting with private sector representatives to ensure that their perspectives 
are reflected in PPIAF advice and activities; 
(iv)  assisting in the supervision of PPIAF activities; and  
(v)  fostering contacts and good working relationships with key government officials 
and representatives of the donor, multilateral, and investor communities.

B.  Program Finances 
 
5.  PPIAF has a two-tier financial structure: a core fund and noncore funds. The core fund 
consists of funds that are not subject to prior restrictions on the choice of country or sector. 
However, contributions to the core fund by regional development banks are limited to eligible

designated for  the  core funds  unless  otherwise  indicated. Table  A2.1  sets  out  the  overall

 ADB’S CONTRIBUTIONS TO THE PUBLIC-PRIVATE INFRASTRUCTURE FACILITY 
AND ADB TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE ACTIVITIES 
 
1.    A trust fund agreement between the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and the World 
Bank for the Public Private Infrastructure Advisory Facility (PPIAF) was signed on 28 August 
2001, 9 April 2003, 2005, and 13 November 2007. An amendment to the trust fund agreement 
for the third contribution was signed on 5 October 2006. This amendment related to a change in 
implementation arrangements in which project management of ADB projects is delegated to 
ADB,  and  procurement  of  goods  and  services  follows  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants and Procurement Guidelines for ADB-initiated projects. On 17 February 2009, the 
current trust fund agreement was extended until 31 October 2012. Assuming the conditions in 
paragraph 15 of the TA report have been satisfied, a revision to the trust fund agreement for this 
contribution be prepared and reflect the conditions around ADB’s access to core funds and 
other noncore funds.
